entries.title: Gaining Spells
details: You can cast a spell only if it is prepared or you have access to it from a magic item.
Class features determine which spells you can access, which are always prepared, and how preparation changes.

entries.title: Preparing Spells
details: If you prepare level 1+ spells, your class feature specifies when you can change the list and how many you can change.
See the Spell Preparation by Class table for a summary.

entries.title: Always-Prepared Spells
details: Spells granted as always prepared do not count against your changeable prepared list.

entries.title: Spell Level
details: Spells have levels 09; cantrips are level 0.
Class rules determine when you gain access to each level.

entries.title: Spell Slots
details: Casting a level 1+ spell expends a slot of the spell's level or higher.
A spell fills a slot of equal or higher level.
Finishing a Long Rest restores expended slots.

entries.title: Casting without Spell Slots
details: Cantrips are cast without slots.
Rituals: spells with the Ritual tag can be cast 10 minutes longer without a slot, but must be prepared.
Special abilities can allow casting a spell without a slot (often limited use).
Magic items like Spell Scrolls can allow slotless casting per item rules.

entries.title: Using a Higher-Level Slot
details: A spell cast with a higher-level slot takes on the slot's level for that casting.
Some spells gain stronger effects when cast at higher levels.

entries.title: School of Magic
details: Each spell belongs to a school; see the Schools of Magic table.
Schools have no rules unless a rule references them.

entries.title: Class Spell Lists
details: Class spell lists are indicated in parentheses after a spell's school.
Some features add spells to your list even if you are not that class.

entries.title: Casting Time
details: Most spells use the Magic action; some use a Bonus Action, Reaction, or longer casting time.
Reaction and some Bonus Action spells are triggered as defined in the spell entry.
If casting time is 1 minute or longer, you take the Magic action each turn and maintain Concentration.
If Concentration is broken during a long casting time, the spell fails and the slot is not expended.

entries.title: One Spell Slot per Turn
details: On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell.

entries.title: Range
details: Range specifies how far from the caster the effect can originate.
Range types include Distance, Touch, and Self.
Movable effects are not restricted by range unless specified.

entries.title: Components
details: A spell may require Verbal (V), Somatic (S), or Material (M) components.
If you cannot provide a required component, you cannot cast the spell.
Verbal components require normal speech; silence or gagging prevents them.
Somatic components require at least one free hand.
Material components are specified in parentheses; they are not consumed unless stated.
If materials are not consumed and have no cost, you can use a Component Pouch or a Spellcasting Focus (if allowed).

entries.title: Duration
details: Durations can be Concentration, Instantaneous, or a Time Span.
While a time-span spell is ongoing, you can dismiss it without an action if you are not Incapacitated.

entries.title: Targets
details: Spells specify what they target and how targets are chosen.
You need a clear path; Total Cover blocks targeting.
You can target yourself unless the spell requires a different or hostile target.
Areas of effect are defined in the glossary: Cone, Cube, Cylinder, Emanation, Line, Sphere.
Targets are unaware unless the effect is perceptible.
Invalid targets cause no effect; if a slot was used, it is still expended.

entries.title: Saving Throws
details: Spells specify the ability used and the result on success or failure.
Spell save DC = 8 + your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus.

entries.title: Attack Rolls
details: Some spells require an attack roll to hit.
Spell attack modifier = your spellcasting ability modifier + your Proficiency Bonus.

entries.title: Combining Spell Effects
details: Different spell effects add together while durations overlap.
The same spell does not stack; the most potent or most recent effect applies.
